21:13 • a day ago

Shyft Network

Veriscope Weekly Regulatory Recap: 7th November to 13th November

Welcome to another edition of Veriscope Regulatory Recap! We are back with exciting news from the world of crypto regulations this week, from US Treasury Chief and Indian Finance Minister discussing crypto regulations to FATF’s push for Travel Rule implementation before the “No Money For Terror” meeting on November 18–19. Shyft’s Veriscope also rolled out a new feature, “Address Proofs,” las

Welcome to another edition of Veriscope Regulatory Recap! We are back with exciting news from the world of crypto regulations this week, from US Treasury Chief and Indian Finance Minister discussing crypto regulations to FATF’s push for Travel Rule implementation before the “No Money For Terror” meeting on November 18–19.

Shyft’s Veriscope also rolled out a new feature, “Address Proofs,” last week, enabling beneficiary VASPs to prove they control the respective crypto wallet address. This, in turn, would ensure that Originator VASPs share critical user data with only the right counterparty VASP for Travel Rule compliance. So, let’s dive straight into it without further ado.

Shyft Network: A “Vital Balancer” Between CeFi & DeFi Amid Upcoming Regulatory Blitzkrieg

The FTX fiasco has got everyone in the crypto space on their toes, compelling virtual asset service providers (VASPs) to come out clean on their exposure to the erstwhile 3rd largest crypto exchange and its native token.

(Image Source)
Speaking of the impact of FTX’s meltdown, it will be multifold. On the one hand, the expectation for sound crypto regulations has also been blown away. And now, instead of regulations that could have spurred crypto innovation, we will get “knee-jerk reactionary” regulation, as per Shyft Network co-founder Joseph Weinberg.

On the other hand, the losses that major institutional investors like Ontario Teacher’s Pension Fund and sequoia Capital experienced with FTX’s collapse will impact the institutional activity within the crypto space.

(Image Source)

However, amid accelerating regulations, Shyft Network will prove itself as a “Vital Balancer” between centralized and decentralized finance. Wishing for the demise of either of these options can strain the crypto industry, as both are required to prevent the upcoming regulatory onslaught.

US Treasury Chief & India Finance Minister Discussed Crypto Regulation

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen met Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman to discuss crypto regulation at the 9th India-U.S. Economic and Financial Partnership meeting.

According to a joint statement by Yellen and Sitharaman after the meeting, the US and India look forward to discussing… digital assets, payment system modernization, and sustainable finance.

(Image Source)

Both promised to strengthen their cooperation in AML/CFT efforts through increased information sharing and coordination, including expediting digital evidence and information sharing for ML/TF investigations.

Following the meeting, Yellen noted that crypto regulation had been a “tremendous focus” of the Biden administration, and while “a good deal of progress” has been made, there’s still some way to go. She also called on taking steps to reduce the cost of cross-border payments.
Indonesia to Tighten Crypto Oversight

According to the latest media reports, Indonesia plans to grant crypto regulatory oversight to the Financial Service Authority (OJK) from Trade Ministry and the Commodity Futures Trading Regulatory Agency to better protect investors.

The new plan, which would regulate and supervise all digital asset-related activities in Indonesia, was presented by Sri Mulyani Indrawati, the country’s finance minister, as part of financial sector legislation currently being debated in parliament.

“We need to build a mechanism of supervision and investor protection that is quite strong and reliable, especially for investment instruments that are high risk,” she told a parliamentary hearing.

The bill was submitted in September and will be enacted into law once greenlighted by the legislative and executive branches.

FTX Collapse could be “Catalyst” for Regulation: SEC Commissioner (Image Source)
The much-publicized collapse of centralized crypto exchange FTX and the subsequent filing of bankruptcy may be the wake-up call US lawmakers need, said SEC commissioner Hester M. Peirce.
While the incident has brought much negative attention to the crypto industry, this act as a “catalyst” that will compel government agencies to “sit down” and create clear and “more comprehensive” regulations, she said.

According to her, if the SEC and CFTC work together, the difficulty of regulating crypto can be solved more efficiently as “having one regulator devoted to crypto could be problematic.”

Peirce suggested that crypto and the underlying blockchain technology could be “integrated into the back end of the financial system,” which requires SEC jurisdiction.

“The SEC would be a good regulator for spot crypto markets if we got our act together,” she said.

FATF Push for “Travel Rule” Implementation (Image Source)

With India ready to host the “No Money For Terror” meeting on November 18–19, the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) is urging countries to implement the crypto Travel Rule to prevent the misuse of virtual assets by terrorist groups.

The upcoming meeting will focus on the misuse of virtual assets and crowd-funding platforms, as well as encourage strong cooperation between financial intelligence units (FIUs) to improve the sharing of information.

The Paris-based financial watchdog recently warned that the implementation of its standard is “going far too slowly.” Out of over 200 countries, only 60 have started to regulate and supervise crypto, while more than 50% “have not even started the process,” said FATF vice president Elisa de Anda Madrazo during the CTC meeting in New Delhi.

“This is very concerning because while standards take time to be implemented, there is a sense of urgency here. Until most countries implement these new rules, it will not be possible to start implementing the travel rule,” she said.
Important Announcement: 10,000 SHFT on Offer! (Image Source)

After Shyft DAO approved the Veriscope VASP grant proposal, an aggregate of 10,000 SHFT has been granted for Virtual Asset Service Providers (VASPs) that integrate to the Veriscope mainnet by September 30, 2022. The fund will enable VASPs to pay the Shyft Network gas fees while using Veriscope. This offer will remain valid until December 31, 2022, or till the VASP exhausts its SHFT grant.

______________________________

VASPs need a Travel Rule Solution to begin complying with the FATF Travel Rule. So, have you zeroed in on it yet? Check out Veriscope, the only frictionless crypto Travel Rule compliance solution.

Visit our website to read more: https://www.shyft.network/veriscope and contact our team for a discussion: https://www.shyft.network/contact

Also, follow us on Twitter, LinkedIn, Discord, Telegram, and Medium for up-to-date news from the world of crypto regulations. Also, sign up for our newsletter to keep up-to-date on all things crypto regulations.

Veriscope Weekly Regulatory Recap: 7th November to 13th November was originally published in Shyft Network on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

19:26 • a day ago

MyDEX

Making ‘better’ easier

Mydex CIC is delighted to say the company has now been awarded a Framework Contract by the UK’s Crown Commercial Services for its G-Cloud public services procurement platform. What is G-Cloud? G-Cloud is a framework by which public and third sector organisations can quickly and easily procure pre-vetted, pre-certified cloud-based solutions. It addresses a fundamental problem facing public a

Mydex CIC is delighted to say the company has now been awarded a Framework Contract by the UK’s Crown Commercial Services for its G-Cloud public services procurement platform.

What is G-Cloud?

G-Cloud is a framework by which public and third sector organisations can quickly and easily procure pre-vetted, pre-certified cloud-based solutions. It addresses a fundamental problem facing public and third sector organisations: the extremely high cost and complexity of finding and sourcing technology=based solutions that fit their needs.

Current procurement processes create huge amounts of friction, effort, risk and cost. (We call it FERC). An organisation wanting to procure a tech-based solution has to invest much time and effort writing a specification. They then have a lengthy process by which the spec is published, bidders send their bids in, and where the organisation has to invest more time and effort assessing the merits and pitfalls of each bid.

Once a potential supplier has been chosen, lengthy negotiations can follow, including about price and associated legal terms and conditions.

Sometimes the costs of going through the procurement process are as big as the size of the contract that’s been awarded. Overall, the process can result in an absurd amount of wasted time, money and effort.

G-Cloud strips much of this FERC away. Thousands of suppliers are listed on the platform and their services are searchable. Services are broken down into modules with fixed, public, pre-set prices, and the procuring organisation can mix and match the modules they need to address their particular problem or requirement. All suppliers are pre-vetted and pre-certified, with standardised legal contracts.

Out go the laborious tasks of spec writing, bid assessments and bespoke contract negotiation. What previously took many months (and huge amounts of time and effort) can now be successfully completed in weeks.

Mydex’s G-Cloud solutions

All of the Mydex solutions listed on the latest G-Cloud framework continue the theme of FERC busting — of taking friction, effort, risk and cost out of the collection, sharing and use of data to deliver better services and lower cost. Each solution can be procured separately, on a modular basis.

Organisations interested in seeing and sourcing these solutions need to register on the Public Procurement Gateway, but what follows is a brief description of what is now available to procure ‘off the shelf’.

Personal data or attribute store

At the heart lies the Mydex personal data or attribute store which provides the citizen with a secure vault to store their information. It is the individual’s secure digital filing cabinet, designed to support them in any aspect of their life, for their entire life. Its data schema are infinitely extensive and it supports self-asserted, self-collected and verified data, including certified copies of proofs issued by third party authorities, in any data format. It provides the citizen with unique encryption with a private key that remains under the sole control of the citizen.

Data can be delivered to this vault via APIs or entered directly, making it portable and exportable under control of the citizen.

Left alone, the personal data or attribute store is a purely private digital filing cabinet. Only the individual can look into it or use it, for example, to bring different data points together and to view them in different ways to provide insights and different perspectives on their lives.

Secure attribute exchange platform

But coupled with the secure attribute exchange platform it transforms the ways in which service providers and citizens do business with each other. With it, service providers can safely, easily and efficiently deposit data into the individual’s personal data store (via secure APIs), and individuals can share data held in their personal data store with service providers (automatically translating data from one format to another as necessary).

By enabling citizens to provide pre-verified proofs-of-claims e.g. age, benefits, right to work, identity it helps eliminate form filling and strips out multiple costs for service providers in collecting and checking data. It operates very much like a line rental on a phone network. Subscribers pay a connection fee to access the service, and there are no transaction fees on top.

Identity as a service

Mydex’s identity as a service gives individuals a unique identifier, which remains under their control, by which they can verify their identity and access services.

Two key benefits of the Mydex approach are that it avoids the fragmentation that occurs when multiple different service providers each try to provide individuals with their own separate identities (the Mydex ID works for all subscribers), while also avoiding the privacy bleed that takes place when individuals use single sign-on tools provided by commercial digital platforms. It meets all Government and security standards, and provides the citizen with an identity for life.

It can be integrated into any environment supporting open standards and protocols and can support a range of multi-factor authentication mechanisms, profile management, identity assurance and age verification to meet diverse needs. Service providers control the end to end journey of registration and authentication and can elect to extend the scope of a service to include profile sharing and passing of personal data into online transactions.

Mydex provides a range of additional modules that address many other service needs.

Inclued platform

Inclued is a citizen and community engagement platform which turns traditional engagement processes on their heads. Under the traditional approach, organisations offering a service seek to publicise this service to potential users in multiple ways, by publishing information about the service on their website, for example. Potential users then have to go searching for the services they need and, if (at last) a fit is found, they then have to go through the often-laborious process of making an application, providing eligibility, and so on.

With Inclued citizens can publish an anonymised profile providing details about themselves. Service providers can search these profiles, and send messages, including offers and incentives to join or take part and notifications, via a web app. This greatly reduces service providers’ costs of ‘going to market’ while citizens can sit back and let the right services come to them. The same platform can be used to recruit communities to take part in projects.

Web app generator as a service

The Inclued interface is an intuitive, easy-to-use web app that can be accessed from anywhere, via which citizens receive invites to any services from subscribers. Web apps are like the apps made available by digital platforms like Apple or Google, except that they are not dependent on these platforms for access, and can be accessed by anyone able to use a web browser.

Unfortunately few public or third sector services currently use web apps because of the cost and complexity of building them. As a result, many services still rely on paper or online forms, which means the ‘last mile’ of service provision remains undigitised, and therefore costly and inefficient.

Mydex’s Web app generator as a service lets non-technical front line service providing teams to define the service they are trying to deliver, including the information they need to collect and provide and to use the resulting requirements and service ‘map’ to automatically generate a web app at a fraction of the cost of traditional approaches.

The web app generator has built-in compliance to all UK Government service design manual guidelines and Digital First Service Standards and allows different roles for different team members e.g. story mapper, journey builder, administrator, content editor and deployment manager. All data required and generated by the resulting web app automatically flows into (and comes out of) the individual’s personal data, thereby protecting their privacy and keeping them in control.

Cluster Collaboration Platform

The Cluster Collaboration Platform meanwhile enables front line service teams that need to work with others from different organisations to safely and easily share the data they need to share in order to provide the best possible service to the citizen.

People have spent many years and huge amounts of time, money and effort trying to solve the governance conundrums of the inter-organisation sharing of personal data. Every time, it has resulted in a complexity catastrophe. By putting citizens’ personal data stores at the heart of the data sharing process, the Cluster Collaboration Platform sidesteps these complexities, enabling organisations across varying sectors and regulatory environments to work together to deliver joined-up services to individual citizens, with GDPR compliance and ethical governance of data assured.

Services operate via secure API’s with the service providers back end systems sending and receiving personal data. Service providers may create specific web applications or native applications for citizens to use that to provide an integrated view of a service.

As a collaboration platform, it enables multiple low-cost community based, community driven, local services.

Consent Management and GDPR Compliance Service

Mydex’s Consent Management and GDPR Compliance Service gives service providers a set of tools and utilities that enables them to meet their legal data protection obligations and to use this process to both cut the costs of compliance and build better working relationships with service users. An important part of the service is efficient mechanisms for when individuals assert their legal rights, for the right to be forgotten or for subject access requests, for example.

Service providers may create defined use cases for data usage sharing to support one or more services, these are added to the platform. When a citizen signs up for a service they formally approve the data usage and sharing. Consent Management enables organisations to integrate seamless consent journeys into existing services, with consents being formally recorded for both the citizen and the service provider. Individuals are equipped with a consent management dashboard for the use of personal data across any sector.

Master Reference Data Service

But not all services need to access and use only personal data. Very often, the most value is created when an individual’s personal data is linked to other non-personal data such as a directory of services that may be relevant to that individual. Mydex’s Master Reference Data Service addresses a long standing problem that all public/third sector organisations are faced with: how to access accurate and timely reference data — look-up tables that they can rely on, whether it is postcodes or directories of service providers.

At the moment they do this by accessing downloadable files or visiting websites. But they then have to integrate this information manually into any apps or services that they build. Often, they pay multiple times to access the same reference data because it is being used for different services.

The Mydex Master Reference data service provides a set of canonical lists that are drawn from authoritative sources and maintained by Mydex which manages all the updates behind the scenes. This greatly reduces the friction, effort, risk and cost of accessing accurate authoritative reference tables.

Orientation, planning and implementation services

Organisations using these services may need some help in terms of orientation, planning and implementation, so there are also specific G-Cloud modules for both the Mydex and Inclued platforms.

Key elements of these services include discovery and scoping (e.g. use cases, data requirements, stakeholder analysis etc), provisioning, configuration, sandbox testing and live operational deployment.

Conclusion

New, better citizen-empowering ways of collecting and using personal data are making dramatic improvements in service productivity and quality possible, aiding citizen access and inclusion and resulting in greatly improved outcomes.

But it has often been hard for service providers to implement these solutions. Traditional public and third sector procurement and project management processes were so complex and time consuming that many were put off even trying. It’s as if, instead of being able to pop out to a local shop to buy a pint of milk, if we wanted a pint of milk we had to tend the cows and venture into fields to milk them ourselves.

Complexity and effort is a barrier to getting things done. Procuring services like those offered by Mydex should be as quick, easy and simple as buying a pint of milk. G-Cloud is a great step forward towards this goal. We look forward to see how it evolves over the coming years.

Making ‘better’ easier was originally published in Mydex on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

15:44 • a day ago

IBM Blockchain

Under FSMA Rule 204(d), digital traceability can save lives by saving food supplies

An oft-overlooked clause of the US FDA’s Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) has the potential to drive global change in the way we sustainably source our food, providing a blueprint for governments around the world on how to create a lasting impact through regulation: digital traceability. In order to adequately and sustainably feed the world’s […] The post Under FSMA Rule 204(d), digital trac

An oft-overlooked clause of the US FDA’s Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) has the potential to drive global change in the way we sustainably source our food, providing a blueprint for governments around the world on how to create a lasting impact through regulation: digital traceability. In order to adequately and sustainably feed the world’s […]

The post Under FSMA Rule 204(d), digital traceability can save lives by saving food supplies appeared first on IBM Supply Chain and Blockchain Blog.

Ocean Protocol

Ocean Protocol Challenge: Predict ETH Price — 2nd Edition

Ocean Protocol Challenge: Predict ETH Price — 2nd Edition Predict ETH prices 12 hours into the future and win $OCEAN prizes! Calling all Oceaners! Are you a passionate DeFi enthusiast or data scientist looking to earn crypto rewards? We are hosting a second Predict ETH crypto data challenge to promote DeFi prediction models on the Ocean Market. Start predicting the price of ETH to win
Ocean Protocol Challenge: Predict ETH Price — 2nd Edition

Predict ETH prices 12 hours into the future and win $OCEAN prizes!

Calling all Oceaners!

Are you a passionate DeFi enthusiast or data scientist looking to earn crypto rewards? We are hosting a second Predict ETH crypto data challenge to promote DeFi prediction models on the Ocean Market. Start predicting the price of ETH to win $OCEAN prizes! Contestants need to predict the price of ETH for 12 hours into the future, submit their price predictions, and describe their solution for a chance to win.

Prize Pool: $5,000 USD /payable in OCEAN

1st place: $2,500

2nd place: $1,500

3rd place: $1,000

The evaluation panel will determine if entries are valid, submitted in good faith, and meet minimum requirements as specified in the challenge description. All valid entries submitted will receive an award of 250 $OCEAN tokens.

How to Enter the Challenge

See the challenge requirements, create your proposal, and submit your predictions all on the ETH Predict challenge page on Questbook.

You can use any data you wish — static data or streams, free or priced, raw data or feature vectors, published in Ocean or not. We included links to some data feeds and AI modelling approaches that you may find helpful in the challenge’s README.

The Challenge:

The submission deadline is Dec 11, 2022 at 23:59 UTC.

Contestants are requested to submit the following:

A .csv file with ETH price predictions over a 12-hour period, with the first prediction presenting the price on Monday December 12, 2022 at 1:00am UTC and a prediction for every hour on the hour after that, for 12 predictions total. A report of 10–15 slides describing your approach, difficulties encountered and insights you gained in making the predictions. Think of this as a “conference presentation” for your work. At least one slide presenting any challenges faced while using the Ocean library and/or recommendations you may have.

Evaluation Criteria

70% of the competition’s score will be objectively measured, based on Normalized Mean Square Error (NMSE) of the predictions (1). The README shows the precise calculations.

20% of the competition’s score will be based on the slides (2), subjectively measured by a panel of judges. The criteria will be like those of a presentation in a technical conference.

10% of the competition’s score will be based on the provision of a feedback slide (3).

Questions?

Meet us on Discord Tuesdays at 3PM UTC for our OCEAN ETH-Predict Challenge Workshop to discuss the challenge’s README, a unique submission example, and Q&A with our team. See our Discord #events-overview channel for details.

About Ocean Protocol

Ocean Protocol is a decentralized data exchange platform spearheading the movement to unlock a New Data Economy, break down data silos, and open access to quality data. Ocean’s intuitive marketplace technology allows data to be published, discovered, and consumed in a secure, privacy-preserving manner by giving power back to data owners, Ocean resolves the tradeoff between using private data and the risks of exposing it.

Ocean Protocol Challenge: Predict ETH Price — 2nd Edition was originally published in Ocean Protocol on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

12:28 • 2 days ago

Tokeny Solutions

5 years of hard work pays off as the tokenization wave begins

The post 5 years of hard work pays off as the tokenization wave begins appeared first on Tokeny.
November 2022 5 years of hard work pays off as the tokenization wave begins

In October, we celebrated our 5th birthday in Luxembourg. Since our inception, we have progressed from a startup to a global leading tokenization solution provider, recognized and trusted by institutions. It was important to us to acknowledge the great work the team has done, so we took three days to meet and celebrate in person with teammates and partners. Let me share with you how we started and where we are heading to.

🥚 Born out of the ICO boom, with compliance and real world assets in mind

2017 was the first crypto boom. It demonstrated that public blockchain had the potential to change the financial world. We had the vision to bring real world assets and financial securities to this shared IT infrastructure to make finance more transparent, real-time, and accessible. Tokeny was founded the same year and started to propose solutions for projects raising funds on blockchain.

We successfully provided software tools to onboard thousands of investors within minutes and to automatically reconcile their payments on the blockchain in order to mint their utility tokens. This demonstrated the power of smart contracts and that a good UX for investors was possible. In 2019, we’ve secured fundraising from Euronext, the largest stock exchange group in Europe, allowing us to develop a complete set of tools for financial actors to easily adopt the technology.

⛓ Creating the open-source security token standard ERC3643

Tokenization relies on smart contracts to represent assets on blockchain. Upon reviewing all existing smart contract standards, we realized that no existing token standard was ensuring compliance properly for tokenized securities. Compliance validations were relying only on wallet addresses or on the software database. In addition, key features for agents were missing (recovery of assets, batch operations, etc.).

To this end, we created the open-source security token standard, ERC3643, using an identity-based compliance approach to ensure on-chain compliance. Also, more than 120 functions of control were added. Now, ERC3643 is becoming the market standard for digital securities as it is adopted by large financial institutions and governments.

🎛 5 years of investment to build solutions covering the whole value chain

ERC3643 is open-source, anyone can freely use it. However, managing smart contracts can be very cumbersome. Issuers and their agents need a robust operating platform to manage their tokens and investors in a secure and efficient way.

The platform needs to scan the blockchain in real time, reconcile blockchain and investors’ data, and allow smooth blockchain-based operations via user-friendly interfaces. In addition, it needs to include more sophisticated functionality such as token recovery, permission delegation, cross-chain capability, and more. After years of development and optimizations, we now offer our customers with complete, compliant and white-label solutions, covering the entire tokenization value chain.

Our hard work is paying off as we are signing large institutions and riding the wave of tokenization. Institutions are realizing that building a platform takes time, is costly, risky, and could prevent them from accessing an interoperable ecosystem of applications and providers. The time to market is the main element to consider for institutions, and our suite of tools allows them to quickly adopt the proven standard to offer blockchain-based services for their investors.

🌐 Growing the ecosystem and preparing for institutional DeFi

Asset issuers and service providers (custodians, KYC providers, data oracles, liquidity providers, DeFi protocols, etc.) are now joining the ERC3643 ecosystem. Issuers immediately access hundreds of service providers, while service providers can offer services to any issuer in the ecosystem. We act as an ecosystem facilitator, ensuring that the technology stack remains interoperable and compatible with all major players of the market.

As the ecosystem grows, all the elements needed for institutional DeFi are coming together: higher quality of tokenized assets, valuation oracles, compliant DeFi protocols, DINO distribution networks for liquidity providers, etc. Our team is ready to assist any players in accessing institutional DeFi, and we expect it to be the next big thing in the tokenization industry.

Thank you for being part of our journey, stay tuned for more exciting updates.

11:57 • 2 days ago

Onfido Tech

Helping people verify their identity first time

Updating Onfido’s ID capture experience to help people submit high-quality photos of their identity documents Overview Context At Onfido, we help protect businesses against fraud by verifying their customers’ identities. This process requires users to take a photo of their identity document and a selfie. Once submitted, machine learning algorithms check both are genuine and match the selfie to
Updating Onfido’s ID capture experience to help people submit high-quality photos of their identity documents Overview Context

At Onfido, we help protect businesses against fraud by verifying their customers’ identities. This process requires users to take a photo of their identity document and a selfie. Once submitted, machine learning algorithms check both are genuine and match the selfie to the photo ID to verify them. To do this, most users provide their photos using our Smart Capture SDK, a drop-in set of screens customers integrate into their app.

Problem

Users frequently submit low-quality photos of their IDs. Low-quality photos make it harder for us to verify their identity, which often means they can’t access our customer’s services. These failed verification attempts cost our customers time and money as their would-be users must try again or give up and drop off entirely.

Goals

Our goals for this project were to:

Help people provide high-quality photos of their IDs using our iOS and Android SDKs. Increase the number of people who get verified on their first attempt. Decrease the number of verifications that fail due to ID-related image quality issues. Team

I led the design process and was responsible for running usability testing. My team included:

1 x Product Designer (myself) 1 x Product Manager 1 x Engineering Lead 3 x Engineers (1 iOS, 1 Android, 1 Backend) 1 x User Researcher 1 x Applied Scientist 1 x Data Analyst Process Discovery

Through our data and user research, we discovered that:

Despite the SDKs already having blur detection, blurry photos were still getting submitted. The most common image quality issues responsible for failed verifications were blur, glare or essential parts of the ID getting cut off (such as the MRZ on a passport photo page). When reviewing a photo, ‘submit photo’ was always the primary button. Because of this, people often submitted photos inattentively, even when their details weren’t clear. They expected the SDK to tell them to retake their photo if it wasn’t good enough. Due to the personal nature of identity documents, most users wanted to review their photos before they submitted them. Exploration

I explored a number of different ways to prevent users from submitting low-quality photos, from automating the review step to capturing a video and using machine learning to select and enhance the best frames.

After discussing the pros and cons of each with the team, we decided on a dual approach. We’d use machine learning algorithms to detect the most common image quality issues and provide instant feedback to users during a smarter review step. With this approach, we’d be able to let users know if there’s an issue with their photo and how to fix it in real-time before submission.

Technical approach

Introducing these new algorithms meant choosing whether to have them as part of the SDK or Onfido’s backend. We decided the backend would be best as we’d be able to:

Use the same solution across platforms instead of needing to create different algorithms for iOS and Android. Improve existing algorithms and introduce new ones to detect other issues (e.g. expired documents) without having to release a new version of the SDK each time. Use more powerful algorithms and not be constrained by the SDK’s file size. Build on top of the Web SDK’s existing Image Quality Service (IQS).

To accommodate this approach, I updated the user flow. Photos are now uploaded to the backend before users review them so that the algorithms can flag any issues first.

Validating our approach

I created some prototypes and ran two rounds of usability testing on the review step, each with ten participants. By changing the primary button to ‘retake photo’ when an issue is detected, users found the review step “makes more sense as it advises you what do to”.

We also ran an A/B test to measure the effectiveness of the new algorithms. The results showed a 16% decrease in identity checks that failed due to image quality issues. We also saw a 2% increase in the number of people successfully verified.

Solution

With the new algorithms, the SDKs give users feedback during the review step if there’s a problem with their photo. If an issue such as a blur is detected, ‘retake photo’ is the primary button. If the photo is ok, then ‘submit photo’ is. This change steers users to retake their photo when needed whilst still allowing them to review it themselves, providing more clarity without compromising control. To prevent users from submitting photos we know aren’t good enough, we also now hide the submit option if an issue gets detected on their first attempt.

Impact

This project was a success on multiple fronts:

We released a new version of the SDK with the changes on iOS and Android. They’re now used by millions of people each month to submit photos of their IDs. We’ve seen a decrease in the number of verifications that fail due to ID-related image quality issues and an increase in the number of people verified on their first attempt since this change. Both have helped contribute to improved customer conversion rates. We put the foundation in place for the team to improve existing algorithms and introduce new ones without having to release a new version of the SDK each time.

Since finishing this project in late 2021, the team have made several improvements, including releasing an improved glare detection algorithm. The foundation we put in place meant we could deliver these improvements to users and start seeing results without relying on customers to adopt the latest SDK version.

Helping people verify their identity first time was originally published in Onfido Product and Tech on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

11:37 • 2 days ago

PingTalk

How Identity Orchestration Accelerates Your Passwordless Vision | Ping Identity

Passwords have been around since the dawn of the digital age and today are a part of our daily routines. Surveys have shown that the average person has 100+ passwords, and it’s only logical that the number will increase as more applications and services emerge. But who really wants more passwords?   Passwords are a great source of frustration for users. The rules behind them continue to g

Passwords have been around since the dawn of the digital age and today are a part of our daily routines. Surveys have shown that the average person has 100+ passwords, and it’s only logical that the number will increase as more applications and services emerge. But who really wants more passwords?

 

Passwords are a great source of frustration for users. The rules behind them continue to get more complex and cumbersome. That in turn leads to more password resets, which require extra steps. In fact, a study of US consumers showed that on average, a consumer abandons 16 online purchases a year due to password frustration.

 

Passwords are probably adding friction to your sales process and affecting your business from capturing revenue.

 

The reason passwords exist is, of course, security. However, the truth behind the effectiveness of passwords is much different. As we have seen time and time again in various high-profile breaches, passwords offer little resistance to malicious actors. Passwords are the most popular and frequent target for hackers looking to steal data or gain remote access.

07:00 • 2 days ago

Ocean Protocol

Data Farming DF10 Completed, DF11 Started

Stakers can claim DF10 rewards. DF11 runs Nov 10–17 2022 1. Overview The Ocean Data Farming program incentivizes the growth of data consume volume in the Ocean ecosystem. It rewards OCEAN for stakers who allocate liquidity to curate data asset with high data consume volume (DCV). To participate, users lock OCEAN to receive veOCEAN, then allocate veOCEAN to promising data assets (data
Stakers can claim DF10 rewards. DF11 runs Nov 10–17 2022 1. Overview

The Ocean Data Farming program incentivizes the growth of data consume volume in the Ocean ecosystem. It rewards OCEAN for stakers who allocate liquidity to curate data asset with high data consume volume (DCV).

To participate, users lock OCEAN to receive veOCEAN, then allocate veOCEAN to promising data assets (data NFTs) via the DF webapp.

DF Round 10 (DF10) is part of DF Beta. DF10 counting started 12:01am Nov 3, 2022, and ended 12:01am Nov 10, 2022. 50K OCEAN worth of rewards were available. LPs can now claim rewards at the DF webapp Claim Portal.

DF11 is part of DF Beta. Counting started 12:01am Nov 10, 2022.

DF11's reward function and parameters are identical to those of DF10 and DF9, which are described in the DF9 launch post.

The rest of this post describes how to claim rewards, and DF11 details.

2. How To Claim Rewards

As an LP (staker), here’s how to claim rewards:

Go to DF webapp Claim Portal Connect your wallet Rewards are distributed on Ethereum mainnet. Click “Claim”, sign the tx, and collect your rewards

Rewards will accumulate over weeks so you can claim rewards at your leisure. If you claim weekly, you can re-stake your rewards for compound gains.

3. DF11 Details

DF11’s reward function and parameters are identical to those of DF10 and DF9.

DF11 is part of DF Beta. DF Beta’s aim is to test the effect of larger incentives, learn, and refine the technology. DF Beta may run 10–20 weeks. In any given week of DF Beta, total budget may be as low as 10K $OCEAN or as high as 100K $OCEAN.

Some key numbers:

Total budget is 50K $OCEAN 50% of the budget goes to passive rewards (25K $OCEAN) — rewarding users who hold veOCEAN (locked OCEAN) 50% of the budget goes to active rewards (25K $OCEAN) — rewarding users who allocate their veOCEAN towards productive datasets (having DCV). Ocean currently supports five production networks: Ethereum Mainnet, Polygon, BSC, EWC, and Moonriver. DF applies to data on all of them.

As usual, the Ocean core team reserves the right to update the DF rewards function and parameters, based on observing behavior. Updates are always announced at the beginning of a round, if not sooner.

Further Reading

The Data Farming Series post collects together key articles, and related resources about DF.

Follow Ocean Protocol on Twitter, Telegram, or GitHub for project announcements. And chat directly with the Ocean community on Discord.

Data Farming DF10 Completed, DF11 Started was originally published in Ocean Protocol on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

18:32 • 5 days ago

Shyft Network

FATF Refutes Crypto Graylisting Speculations

Media reports were abuzz this week with news around FATF’s decision to penalize countries that haven’t yet implemented the agency’s proposed guidelines on crypto anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorist financing (CTF). However, it turned out to be a speculation, and nothing more, as a FATF spokesperson denied any changes to how the agency graylists countries or tracks cryptocurrencies.
Media reports were abuzz this week with news around FATF’s decision to penalize countries that haven’t yet implemented the agency’s proposed guidelines on crypto anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorist financing (CTF). However, it turned out to be a speculation, and nothing more, as a FATF spokesperson denied any changes to how the agency graylists countries or tracks cryptocurrencies. Although global regulatory response towards cryptocurrencies is still evolving, authorities worldwide have started preparing to bring the nascent assets within the regulatory net.

According to an Al Jazeera report dated November 7th, the global financial watchdog, FATF, is preparing to conduct annual checks. It aims to ensure countries are enforcing the anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorist financing (CTF) rules on virtual asset service providers (VASPs) operating in their jurisdictions.

(Image Source)

The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) has no enforcement powers and mostly relies on governments to enforce its recommendations. However, countries that fail to comply risk serious reputational harm, which could halt investment flows and access to the global financial system.

Annual Reviews vs. Evaluations

Using annual reviews over reciprocal evaluations would allow non-compliant countries less time to implement FATF-set standards. This, in turn, will raise the risk of being added to the graylist.

The “gray” list refers to the list of countries the FATF deems as “Jurisdictions under Increased Monitoring.”

This list is different from the FATF’s blacklist, which relates to countries with significant strategic weaknesses concerning money laundering, including Iran and North Korea.

There are currently 23 countries on that list, including Syria, South Sudan, Haiti, and Uganda.

Crypto hotspots such as the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the Philippines are also on the FATF’s blacklist. Still, according to the global financial watchdog, both countries made high-level policy commitments to working with the global financial watchdog to bolster their AML and CTF regimes.

FATF’s Denial (Image Source)
However, the report was later refuted by the agency. A FATF spokesman told Al Jazeera that the regulatory body’s discussions are confidential and do not comment on media speculation.

He reiterated that the organization has not changed how it tracks virtual assets or adds countries to its graylist.

Slow Implementation

In April 2022, the global financial watchdog reported that many countries, including those that had implemented VASP licensing regime, were in noncompliance with its standards for AML and CFT.

Current Outlook on Crypto Regulations (Image Source)

The global regulatory response towards crypto assets varies widely, with some countries adopting the new technology while others strictly or completely limiting its legal uses. But agencies have begun to look closely at cryptocurrencies and how they can fit them into existing financial regulations.

Overall, the regulatory landscape for cryptocurrencies is still evolving, and it will likely take some time before there is a clear global consensus on how to deal with them.

______________________________

VASPs need a Travel Rule Solution to begin complying with the FATF Travel Rule. So, have you zeroed in on it yet? Check out Veriscope, the only frictionless crypto Travel Rule compliance solution.

Visit our website to read more: https://www.shyft.network/veriscope and contact our team for a discussion: https://www.shyft.network/contact

Also, follow us on Twitter, LinkedIn, Discord, Telegram, and Medium for up-to-date news from the world of crypto regulations. Sign up for our newsletter to keep up-to-date on all crypto regulations.

FATF Refutes Crypto Graylisting Speculations was originally published in Shyft Network on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

16:10 • 5 days ago

Forgerock Blog

A New Era in Access Management

As we enter 2023, Gartner calls for convergence, resilience, and cost-effectiveness In its new report, the 2022 Magic Quadrant™ for Access Management, Gartner® brings attention to the increasingly critical role of access management in the enterprise — along with the fact that it has become a prime target for attackers. The crux of the report reveals that modern threats and economic constraints
As we enter 2023, Gartner calls for convergence, resilience, and cost-effectiveness

In its new report, the 2022 Magic Quadrant™ for Access Management, Gartner® brings attention to the increasingly critical role of access management in the enterprise — along with the fact that it has become a prime target for attackers. The crux of the report reveals that modern threats and economic constraints demand more resilient and cost-effective access management.

It has become clear that enterprises need to evolve their CIAM and workforce strategies to reduce risk, create efficiencies, and support all their use cases.

In its Magic Quadrant report, Gartner provides a distillation of all its research on access management products, vendors, and industry trends. This year's report highlighted several trends, including the need for identity threat detection and response (ITDR) to protect against breaches caused by credential misuse, which now represent 40% of all breaches. Gartner also identified journey orchestration as a way to reduce risk, cost, and complexity. Weak and compromised passwords remain a huge threat, and Gartner called attention to the need for passwordless and phishing-resistant authentication. Finally, the report emphasized the need for converged platforms, which improve security and create cost efficiencies.

We're honored to have been named a Leader in this market for the third consecutive year by Gartner Inc. in their 2022 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Access Management.

The enhancements we made to our CIAM solution are aimed at meeting the evolving needs of the enterprise — especially related to managing customers' identities and making personalized journeys easier with new orchestration capabilities.

We are proud of the innovation and new capabilities we've introduced to the ForgeRock Identity Platform to help our customers manage, secure, and govern all their identities, and we're excited about this year's advancements in key areas:

Expansion of our platform's orchestration engine with the broadest library of pre-built, no-code journey nodes AI-driven access and governance for identity threat detection and response (ITDR) Passwordless authentication that makes access more convenient for users and eliminates the threat of compromised credentials, the most common cause of breaches

To learn more about the access management market, I'd encourage you to read this latest version of the Gartner® Magic Quadrant™. I believe Gartner analysis can help you select a partner that can support your enterprise's need for a modern access management solution. Download a complimentary copy of the report now.

*Gartner "Magic Quadrant for Access Management" by Analyst(s): Henrique Teixeira, Abhyuday Data, Michael Kelley, James Hoover, Brian Guthrie. November 1, 2022.

This graphic was published by Gartner, Inc. as part of a larger research document and should be evaluated in the context of the entire document. The Gartner document is available upon request from ForgeRock.

Gartner does not endorse any vendor, product or service depicted in its research publications, and does not advise technology users to select only those vendors with the highest ratings or other designation. Gartner research publications consist of the opinions of Gartner's research organization and should not be construed as statements of fact. Gartner disclaims all warranties, express or implied, with respect to this research, including any warranties of merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose. Gartner and Magic Quadrant are registered trademarks of Gartner, Inc. and/or its affiliates in the U.S. and internationally and is used herein with permission. All rights reserved.

16:00 • 5 days ago

This week in identity

E14 - Whitehall IDM London / AI+ML & Automation / IGA / Machine Identity / Identity Business Cases / Identity for Zero Trust

This week Simon and David met up face to face at the Whitehall IDM Conference in London.  This one day event covered a host of topics, case studies and vendor pitches.  Simon and David pick out the best and most interesting aspects focused on the rise of AI+ML in authentication and IGA - asking the question is identity becoming a big data problem?  They discuss the emergence of mach

This week Simon and David met up face to face at the Whitehall IDM Conference in London.  This one day event covered a host of topics, case studies and vendor pitches.  Simon and David pick out the best and most interesting aspects focused on the rise of AI+ML in authentication and IGA - asking the question is identity becoming a big data problem?  They discuss the emergence of machine and service identities - what it is, who will own it and how it works.  They cover cyber insurance the ever growing need to articulate the business case for IAM and how identity for zero trust architectures is for small and large organisations alike.

14:48 • 5 days ago

KuppingerCole

Enhancing Zero Trust in a ServiceNow Environment

by Martin Kuppinger Zero Trust has been established as the guiding principle for cybersecurity. The “don’t trust, always verify” approach stands for methods that don’t rely only on singular security tools, such as the traditional network perimeter firewall, to keep attackers out. Instead, Zero Trust builds on layered security and repeated or  continuous verification. The concept of Zero Tr

by Martin Kuppinger

Zero Trust has been established as the guiding principle for cybersecurity. The “don’t trust, always verify” approach stands for methods that don’t rely only on singular security tools, such as the traditional network perimeter firewall, to keep attackers out. Instead, Zero Trust builds on layered security and repeated or  continuous verification.

The concept of Zero Trust has evolved beyond a network perspective, restricting lateral movements of users once they have passed the firewall. It involves a broader model that looks at many different layers of access and permissions. Zero Trust spans identities, devices, networks, systems, applications, data, and software.

The Role of Identity in Zero Trust

Identities are where Zero Trust starts, with user authentication and with IGA (Identity Governance and Administration) solutions managing the user accounts and their entitlements, but also providing  access governance capabilities, including regular review and recertification, making it a key component of a Zero Trust model. In the future, we expect – also following the NIST Zero Trust concept of policy-based controls – an uptake of policy-based, real-time enforcement and verification of access authorizations.

Zero Trust  on ServiceNow Every IT environment must be protected against cyberattacks, and to achieve this, Zero Trust must become ubiquitous. ServiceNow, delivers a range of business applications on the platform to protect enterprises. With its capabilities  for managing IT services and assets, as well as GRC (Governance, Risk, and Compliance) and support for SecOps (Security Operations), it’s a smart way to start implementing Zero Trust with your existing IT Service Management (ITSM) investment.

The criticality of ServiceNow becomes obvious when looking at some of the use cases. CMDBs are an important repository when it comes to advanced device management in the context of Zero Trust. Device verification must build on valid information. With its ITSM capabilities supporting the management of employees, contractors, and partners and their entitlements, e.g., in manual fulfilment, ServiceNow also must be protected against fraudulent use.

There are various further use cases:  

the role of CMDBs for delivering attributes that are used for defining entitlements, and for real-time authorization; the integrated Risk Management capabilities; the protection of workflows in Portfolio Management; and IT and Security Operations, that is both a solution for better managing and protecting the IT infrastructure, and a potential attack target for taking control about large parts of the IT infrastructure.

ServiceNow  requires  strong identity management to govern users and their entitlements. This goes beyond the capabilities of ITSM solutions, such as ServiceNow, that are primarily focused on supporting manual fulfilment activities within IGA.

Zero Trust with ServiceNow and Clear Skye IGA

Clear Skye is an IGA solution built natively on ServiceNow. It utilizes a wide range of platform capabilities, such as the data model and database, workflows, and the ServiceNow user interface. While supporting a wide range of applications, a particular strength of Clear Skye derives from being native to the ServiceNow platform and the ability to manage identities and their access in this environment.

With that, Clear Skye provides an essential building block for enhancing Zero Trust to ServiceNow environments and beyond. It can protect both the various applications within the ServiceNow environment and other, external systems and applications via connectors.

Commissioned by ClearSkye

11:00 • 5 days ago

Innopay

European Data Summit 2022

European Data Summit 2022 from 30 Nov 2022 till 02 Dec 2022 trudy 11 November 2022 - 08:53 Berlin The 5th European Data Summit will take place from 30 November to 2 December in Berlin. INNOPAY’s Mariane ter Veen has been invited to chair a panel discussion on the second day
European Data Summit 2022 from 30 Nov 2022 till 02 Dec 2022 trudy 11 November 2022 - 08:53 Berlin

The 5th European Data Summit will take place from 30 November to 2 December in Berlin. INNOPAY’s Mariane ter Veen has been invited to chair a panel discussion on the second day of the event.

The theme of this year’s European Data Summit is ‘Sustainable Competition’. This refers to European efforts to tackle current challenges – including digitalisation, equitable globalisation and sustainability – through international coordination and a contemporary regulatory framework.

On the second day of the summit (from 14:50-15:40h), Mariane will moderate a panel discussion on ‘Data Markets under the Framework of the Data Act’. The panelists will include Wolfgang Kerber (University of Marburg), Johannes Jänicke (Head of Office for MEP Damian Boeselager, VoltEurope), Michael Dose (Federation of German Industries), Moritz Hennemann (University of Passau) and Malte Beyer-Katzenberger (European Commission).

For more details and registration, go to the Konrad Adenauer Stiftung's website.

18:14 • 6 days ago

1Kosmos BlockID

Authenticate 2022: How Web 3.0 Will Reshape Authentication

In this vlog, our VP of Product Marketing, Robert MacDonald, sat down with our CMO, Michael Cichon to chat about his experience at the 2022 FIDO Authenticate conference. He also gives insights into his session, “How Web 3.0 Will Reshape Authentication“. Michael Cichon: All right. Hello everybody. This is Michael Cichon, Chief Marketing Officer at … Continued The post Authenticate 2022: How Web 3

In this vlog, our VP of Product Marketing, Robert MacDonald, sat down with our CMO, Michael Cichon to chat about his experience at the 2022 FIDO Authenticate conference. He also gives insights into his session, “How Web 3.0 Will Reshape Authentication“.

Michael Cichon:

All right. Hello everybody. This is Michael Cichon, Chief Marketing Officer at 1Kosmos. I’m here today with Robert MacDonald, our VP of Product Marketing. Robert, you recently went to the FIDO Authenticate conference. I want to chat with you about that. How was the event?

 

Robert MacDonald:

It was great. It was very well attended. It was in Seattle, so got a chance to go out west and attend the event. About 500 people or so. Very well organized, lots of really good presentations and met a lot of really good people while I was there.

 

Michael Cichon:

Awesome. Well, let’s take a half step backwards. I’m familiar with FIDO and you probably are, but for folks who are not familiar with the FIDO Alliance, can you talk about what it is?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Sure. FIDO Alliance, it stands for Fast Identity Online. They’re a consortium that works at delivering a passwordless experience primarily for consumers. There is a workforce integration with them as well, but they’re trying to get customers secure access to things online is really their focus.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay, and step away from passwords. That makes a lot of sense.

 

Robert MacDonald:

That’s right.

 

Michael Cichon:

Your presentation was interesting. The title was what? Web 3.0? What was the title of your session?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yeah, it was How Web 3.0 Will Reshape Authentication was the presentation. Funny enough, like I said earlier, there was lots of presentations. Every presentation that I sat in on talked about passwords and talked about the timeline of passwords that the industry has gone through and how FIDO is going to help reshape that, which aligned very well into what my presentation got into.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay. All right, so let’s take this one step a time. Web 3.0. Just set the baseline. What is Web 3.0 or Web three?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yeah, it’s known as either of those things and it’s the next iteration of what the web is going to look like. Web one, back when you and I were less gray Michael, was static read only webpages. That was kind of 1900’s into the 2000’s. Then Web two came along, which is kind of what we’re really used to these days. That had a centralized information centric content way about it. That’s your Facebook’s, your LinkedIn’s, YouTube, TikTok, all those kinds of things. Now, Web three is the next iteration of how the web is going to work and that promises more user-centric, decentralized, secure, and funny enough, private engagement online. Now we know that privacy in general online is a bit of an issue as it stands currently, but all of that’s going to change with Web three.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay. All right, so how does Web three affect the future of authentication?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yes, that’s a good question. There’s a couple of things. From an authentication standpoint, what’s going to happen is that people are going to be more identifiable online. What I mean by that is that we’re going to have known identities as we’re engaging with people online. There’s going to be steps or processes involved where people will have a digital wallet and that digital wallet will hold their identity. That identity in that digital wallet will be used to authenticate people as we go forward in this new world.

 

Michael Cichon:

Let’s just be clear about something here. The web is still a place where people can behave anonymously. I mean, kind of like walking through a crowded stadium. You’re not declaring yourself to everybody you pass by, but in certain instances, people want to declare their identity when they access their bank account, for example. They don’t want other folks declaring an identity that will give them access to that.

 

Robert MacDonald:

That’s right.

 

Michael Cichon:

You’re talking about the digital identity for authentication or for logging in, correct?

 

Robert MacDonald:

That’s right. The digital identification for logging in and also just knowing who somebody is. If you look at the way in which identity is managed online now, all of these organizations own your identity. Facebook has an identity of you, Google has one, your bank has one, the government has one. Anywhere you’ve put in a username and password to some degree has a version of your identity, whatever that might be. That’s why you can log into things with your Facebook account or your Google account or your LinkedIn account as example, but they own your identity there and they monetize it in a lot of cases. That’s where the privacy concerns kind of come into play.

What’s going to happen now is that you are going to then own that identity and you’re going to choose to allow maybe Facebook or Google or somebody else to have access to it when you are authenticating. Instead of using the identity they’ve given you to log in, you’ll use your identity to log in where they’ve added, how would I say that? A debit card into your wallet. When you use your debit card to log into an ATM, that’s your identity to get that money out so they would put something into your wallet for you to be able to authenticate with your identity. Does that make sense?

 

Michael Cichon:

Well, kind of, but we use the word identity a lot and I’m wondering why do I need an identity? I had passwords before. I’ll just use a biometric. Why do I need an identity?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yeah, so I mean, identity, the way it stands now, it’s proof of possession. You have a username or yeah, proof of possession. You have something you know, you know the username and the password. Maybe you might get a one time password that goes along with that, but at the end of the day, it doesn’t really prove who you are when you authenticate into something.

What Web three is promising is that every time you now authenticate, I know that it’s Michael. It’s not somebody else using Michael’s username and password, it can only be Michael and I don’t want to say the seismic shift, but that’s the significant shift in all of this. It can only be the owner of that wallet which is cryptographically locked down. It has private and public. We won’t get into the background behind all of it, but at the end of the day, it can only be that person that owns the wallet that can authenticate and that’s really the big shift.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay, so if it’s a biometric, then it’s tied to the person or to the identity, so to speak I guess.

 

Robert MacDonald:

That’s correct. Absolutely, yep, that’s exactly right.

 

Michael Cichon:

Well, did you have a chance to sit in on other presentations at the event?

 

Robert MacDonald:

I did. I got a chance to see a couple. I got a chance to see a bunch of them actually. It’s funny, almost every presentation had some sort of, I mentioned earlier a timeline of passwords and how passwords have been used over time and what we’ve done to try to mask or secure that password because as I mentioned earlier, all a password does is just it’s a proof that you know the password, it’s not a proof of who you actually are. The way in which that discussion was formulated was kind of fun to watch, especially based on what we do here at 1Kosmos. Everybody kind of started with that and where the future of FIDO and this identification online is going is exactly in our wheelhouse here at 1Kosmos.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay. Well, I mean the password has worked for 60 some years.

 

Robert MacDonald:

60 years. Yeah, absolutely, 60 years.

 

Michael Cichon:

When you start to have 100, 150, 200 of these things, a little bit unwildly to private and-

 

Robert MacDonald:

That was, not to interrupt you, but that was an interesting stat. There was, a CISO got on stage and said on average people have 140 credentials for digital assets that they need access to. Whether that be things that you do at work, things that you do in your personal life, all of the different apps you have on your phone that require a username and password, all the websites that you want to have access to, all the things you have access to at work. There’s a lot of credentials out there that really don’t prove identity of anybody at all.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay, well, what were maybe one or two of the top questions that you were being asked when you were running through your Web 3.0 Presentation?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yeah, the one question I got asked was how does that wallet transfer itself as we go through different use cases? That was a great question. Specifically workforce and customer. How does that, is there two or do you just use the one? The reply to that is just like your wallet that you carry around in your pocket, it’s used the same way.

When you go and start at a new job, they’re going to ask for your identification so you can share that identification with a new employer to fill out your I9, I think you guys have in the US. We have similar things here in Canada as well, but you’re going to use that digital wallet for that. You’re also going to use it for when you go to apply for a new mortgage or a new loan for a car or just trying to get access to government services. That wallet’s going to be the digital format of what you use today in a real life format.

 

Michael Cichon:

Isn’t Apple doing things with a wallet?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yeah, so there’s lots of talk around the new passkey which is coming. Which is Google’s and Microsoft’s and Apple’s version of this kind of digital identity wallet. There’s lots of discussion around that. It’s still really early on. You’re going to have a public and private key that you can identify yourself in the Apple environment or the Google environment or the Microsoft environment. The issue as it stands right now because it’s so early on, is that that’s not interoperable. There’s a bit of a hurdle there where it works within their own ecosystem, but as soon as you step outside of that, well now I need new wallets again. That kind of defeats the purpose. That’s still early on.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay. Was there any talk about the [inaudible 00:11:06] standards at all?

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yeah, there was. Being able to prove identity with a high assurance, there was some discussion around that and how organizations are going to go about trying to implement that in a digital first environment. Again, still early on from a FIDO perspective in terms of how they’re going to integrate with that. We know here at 1Kosmos, we have certified ways of doing that right out of the gate.

By the looks of it, Michael, everybody’s starting to turn in that direction, but they’re still trying to figure out how it’s going to work, even though we already have a solution that will more than get people there. That’s why I had such a high, I did have a very high turnout for my talk, just as an aside, which was great. A lot of people came to listen to a marketing guy talk which was pretty surprising. At the end of the day, there were a lot of questions afterwards around how do I verify identity and what’s that process look like and how are you going to store the identities and things along those lines.

 

Michael Cichon:

Okay. Well, we’re going to put that presentation on our website here with a full transcript shortly. I know FIDO has been at this for quite a while, at least 10 years or so, evolving along this journey. I’m sure we’ll be participating next year.

 

Robert MacDonald:

We will be.

 

Michael Cichon:

Looking forward to that.

 

Robert MacDonald:

Yeah, thanks for having me today. It was a great presentation. Lots of great feedback on it and go check it out on our website.

 

Michael Cichon:

That’s awesome. I heard great things about it, Robert, good job.

 

Robert MacDonald:

Thanks, appreciate it.

 

Michael Cichon:

 

Thanks a lot and have a good rest of your day.

The post Authenticate 2022: How Web 3.0 Will Reshape Authentication appeared first on 1Kosmos.

20:17 • 6 days ago

Forgerock Blog

For an Indepth Look at CIAM, Read the Forrester Wave™

At ForgeRock, we have great respect for the Forrester Wave report due to its deep analysis, and we are thrilled to have been named a leader in their report, The Forrester Wave™: Customer Identity and Access Management, Q4 2022. Forrester researched, analyzed, and scored customer identity and access management (CIAM) vendors based on a range of 22 criteria that represent important capabilities f

At ForgeRock, we have great respect for the Forrester Wave report due to its deep analysis, and we are thrilled to have been named a leader in their report, The Forrester Wave™: Customer Identity and Access Management, Q4 2022.

Forrester researched, analyzed, and scored customer identity and access management (CIAM) vendors based on a range of 22 criteria that represent important capabilities for enterprises evaluating CIAM for themselves. The research is intensive, including a detailed questionnaire, hours of live demos, multiple briefings, and customer interviews.

Because of the depth of the Forrester analysis, we are particularly proud to have earned the highest scores in both the current offering and strategy categories. The current offering category includes criteria such as data orchestration, users and roles, customer identity verification and registration, authentication methods, customer self-service, and reporting and dashboarding. The strategy category includes the criteria of product vision, execution roadmap, market approach, planned enhancements, supporting products and services, partner ecosystem, delivery model and commercial model.

About ForgeRock CIAM, the report noted, "The solution is a match for organizations that need to map complex-to-very-complex customer registration, authentication, and self-service workflows to a CIAM solution and have internal CIAM administrator expertise and staffing."

For us this description encapsulates exactly what we've aimed to do over the years with our CIAM solution — and it just continues to get better, with more robust orchestration, broad integrations, a range of authentication methods, and more.

This year, we introduced significant enhancements to our orchestration engine that make it easier to create user personalization and self-service. We also simplified authentication by extending the FIDO2 WebAuthn standard to enable passwordless and usernameless login, and we introduced behavioral analytics for authentication and authorization that enable customers to make smart, fast access decisions powered by AI.

As consumers spend more time carrying out digital interactions with brands, government entities, financial institutions, healthcare providers, and others, they have become far more sophisticated and they expect a personalized and secure online experience. Our focus has been to make it as easy as possible for our customers to deliver those experiences.

One customer, Partners Health Management, is using ForgeRock CIAM to create a 360-degree view of member information in order to offer more personalized care. They're using our single sign-on to bolster security and improve the experience for members and providers. Tracy Styles, Partners' IT Support Services Manager, wrote: "A primary advantage of ForgeRock is its ease of use. We considered several solutions on the market, but we found that ForgeRock was definitely the easiest to work with."

We know that large brands face stiff competition as they become increasingly digital, and user experience is a huge factor in their ability to acquire, engage, and retain customers. We've focused on delivering CIAM capabilities that provide highly personalized and secure digital experiences that increase customer satisfaction and build loyalty.

I encourage you to download the report to understand the criteria for which Forrester evaluated the 15 CIAM vendors. The report distills many months of research into an easily consumable format with specific recommendations for availability, scale, and risk-based authorization, as well as the capabilities you may want to evaluate as you select a CIAM partner.
